review.title: Modern WLAN Fingerprinting Indoor Positioning Methods and Deployment Challenges
review.abstract: Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) has become a promising choice for indoor positioning as the only existing and established infrastructure, to localize the mobile and stationary users indoors. However, since WLAN has been initially designed for wireless networking and not positioning, the localization task based on WLAN signals has several challenges. Amongst the WLAN positioning methods, WLAN fingerprinting localization has recently achieved great attention due to its promising results. WLAN fingerprinting faces several challenges and hence, in this paper, our goal is to overview these challenges and the state-of-the-art solutions. This paper consists of three main parts: 1) Conventional localization schemes; 2) State-of-the-art approaches; 3) Practical deployment challenges. Since all the proposed methods in WLAN literature have been conducted and tested in different settings, the reported results are not equally comparable. So, we compare some of the main localization schemes in a single real environment and assess their localization accuracy, positioning error statistics, and complexity. Our results depict illustrative evaluation of WLAN localization systems and guide to future improvement opportunities.

sections.text: This motivated recent work to limit the positioning algorithms to a subset of RPs that have similar characteristics. In other words, a rough localization level reduces the search space of the user's location to a smaller number of RPs, followed by a finer search based on RPs. This process is typically referred to as radio map clustering or spatial filtering, and these terms are used reciprocally in this context. Clustering is a process in which the members of a cluster are based on similarity. A representative value of the fingerprints shows the characteristics of each cluster and is used for rough localization methods.

sections.heading: X. HETEROGENEOUS DEVICES
sections.text: One of the problems associated with the use of fingerprinting approaches is that wireless devices do not read the same RSS readings when in the same position, mainly due to heterogeneous reception characteristics of embedded network cards. Rapid growth of wireless devices of different manufacturers caused hardware variations between devices or even between models (of the same manufacturer), such as the gain of the receiving antenna, the position of the antenna on the device, sensitivity and characteristics of the operating system (OS). Hardware variations can significantly affect the positioning accuracy of RSS-based WiFi localization systems. RSS data (fingerprints and online measurements) can be transformed using linear regression, expectation maximization and neural networks [153]. The Pearson correlation coefficient was also used to determine the similarity between RSS fingerprints and online measurements.

metadata.abstractText: Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) has become a promising choice for indoor positioning as the only existing and established infrastructure, to localize the mobile and stationary users indoors. However, since WLAN has been initially designed for wireless networking and not positioning, the localization task based on WLAN signals has several challenges. Amongst the WLAN positioning methods, WLAN fingerprinting localization has recently achieved great attention due to its promising results. WLAN fingerprinting faces several challenges and hence, in this paper, our goal is to overview these challenges and the state-of-the-art solutions. This paper consists of three main parts: 1) Conventional localization schemes; 2) State-of-the-art approaches; 3) Practical deployment challenges. Since all the proposed methods in WLAN literature have been conducted and tested in different settings, the reported results are not equally comparable. So, we compare some of the main localization schemes in a single real environment and assess their localization accuracy, positioning error statistics, and complexity. Our results depict illustrative evaluation of WLAN localization systems and guide to future improvement opportunities.
